answers.answer: I don't know any doctors outside of my area, but as for Medicaid paying for gastric bypass surgery, first know what qualifies for Medicaid period.  They are so strict.  Medicare began to pay for the surgery recently, I heard, so Medicaid might also if there were serious medical reasons why only the surgery would help you lose the weight -- and you must be at least 100 pounds over your ideal weight to begin with, then must have a few debilitating conditions caused by or exacerbated by the excess weight -- like diabetes, asthma, sleep apnea, arthritis.  Most insurances want documentation that you tried other weight loss measures for at least 6 months and failed, thus you need the surgery.  It is not an easy way out and usually requires weeks or months of attending meetings and support groups BEFORE the operation, lots of tests and counseling and also strict dieting beforehand to be sure you are serious about it, understand it and lose some weight to lighten the liver in advance of the operation if it is being done by laparascope.  They tell you not to get pregnant for at least a year after the surgery.  You must take lots of vitamins and other nutritional supplements for the rest of your life post surgery, and even more so if you get pregnant.
